oai_dc:dc.dc:title: French. Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 40 c
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 40 c. Newspaper clipping: Wilson Plea For Suffrage. Democratic Party Pledge, He Telegraphs Tennessee Senate. March 1, 1917.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Politics & government; Clippings; Scrapbooks; Women; Women's suffrage;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: C.M. McClung Historical Collection, Knox County Public Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: For information on license and use fees and acquiring high-resolution image files, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8814. Please provide a brief description of the material.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: WILSON PLEA FOR SUFFRAGE. Democratic Party Pledged, He Telegraphs Tennessee Senate. An earnest hope that the Tennessee senate will reconsider its recent action in rejecting a woman suffrage bill was expressed by President Wilson in a telegram yesterday to the president of the senate. The measure already had passed the lower house of the legislature, and the president said he felt the upper house was shirking a moral responsibility when it refused to accept it. The telegram follows: "Hon. W. R. Crabtree, president of the Tennessee senate: May I not express my earnest hope that the senate of Tennessee will reconsider the vote by which it rejected the legislation extending the suffrage to women? Our party is so distinctly pledged to its passage that it seems to me the moral obligation is complete. "WOODROW WILSON."
